reviewText:
Oh my god this game is amazing.

Pros: I lived long enough to see the future

Cons: All of my furniture is now in the kitchen.
voteText: 53 of 56 people (95%) found this review helpful 63 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Upon entering the game the first impression I got was a tron vibe. The graphics are simplistic and colorful but have a sharp design style.

The opening lobby is an empty room that contains a number of pedestals with different difficultly levels on each one. initially, the only selectable difficulties are Zen (practice mode) and easy.

I started off with easy mode.

The ball is tee'd up for you to hit and the controls are simple. You swing at the ball and, depending on how hard and what angle you hit it at, it will direct your shot. You want to aim at the sweetspot (outside edges) or angle your shot to bounce off of one or multiple walls. The object, just like pong, is to outwit and outshoot your AI opponent looking to return your serve.

Also, it is good to note there is a leaderboard which I think is a staple and necessary in any arcade type game. It's just another carrot on a stick to keep users striving to do better and encourages players to continue coming back to the game. In the current iteration the leaderboard is only visible once you enter the room. My suggestion is having a way to bring up the leaderboard without having to leave the game and come back.

After some witty quips from my computer opponent I took my shot. WHAM, ACE +100 points. First impressions are great, the accuracy relies completely on the user ability to control the motion controls and the speed in which the shot is taken.

The AI opponent is comical with its retorts and it motivates me to hit my shots correctly.

There are 5 rounds and the player has to reach 5 points in any game, before the AI, to move onto the next round.

I did well and made my way through easy without too much difficulty and was very amazed at how much fun it is to play. I quickly restarted easy to get a better position on the leaderboard.

After getting my bearings I moved onto medium difficulty.

My first impression was that the room increased in size. Ok, that's a cool idea and mechanic.

Quickly, I realized my 7 ft tall ceilings were not going to suffice for any difficulty past easy.

I tried my best to not crush my ceilings, but unfortunately a number of shots went above my reach and it happened regardless.

I made my way through Medium with some lackluster results after restarting a couple times and having learned to let some shots just go by to save my drop-tile ceilings.

I moved onto hard and the room grew bigger. After the first return, I had to leave as a lot of the shots were above my head.

After trying out Zen difficulty I found an equal amount of fun to be had in this very different racquetball type style training simulator.

I did not notice any bugs in the initial testing I've done but will continue to check out the game and see if I find any in time.

So, after an hour of testing I think this game has a ton of potential. The controls are very intuitive and the gameplay is inviting and fun. The difficulty ramps up fairly but my main complaint is that you would probably need at least 9' ceilings in the games current iteration if you are a tall individual like me at 6'3."

reviewText: PSA: Make sure you do not have any objects that will break anywhere near your play space or else you will damage/hurt yourself or your VR remotes.
voteText: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I was provided a beta key by the developers prior to release.

HoloBall is a mix between Pong and racquetball, stylized with Tron-like art animations. The gameplay is simple: score against an AI by hitting the ball with one of your paddles. The game's difficulty ramps up as it continues and each round introduces a modifier such as speeding up the AI or increasing hit power.

Leaderboards encourage replayability and I'd love to see online multiplayer in the future. One thing to note is that you'll be swinging your controllers pretty hard. Make sure you have adequate play space and are aware of your position in your room. I'd personally like to see an outline of the play space much like Space Pirate Trainer to increase positional awareness. (Update: The developer has since added this along with other suggestions sent pre-release. Excellent turn around!) My play space is about 3.3m x 2.8m and I didn't have any issues beyond being overly cautious.

HoloBall takes a classic game into the world of VR and executes on this idea well. This is well worth the cost of admission, especially once you consider the launch sale.
voteText: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText: I bought this game thinking it would be some quick easy fun but I did not expect it to be this GOOD! I got wrapped in the environment and I was determined to beat that condescending AI square. Fast forward 1.5 hours later and I have the top scores in two categories and I feel like I just had a decent workout.\n\nThis might actually be my favorite VR game to date and it is definitely the first one that I can't wait to get back home to play again. I can't recommend this game enough especially at this great price!
voteText: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Disclaimer: I received free a key on Reddit from the developers

HoloBall is a great little mashup of racket-ball and pong, mixed with the post-apocalyptic robot humor that reminds me a bit of GladOS from Portal. Absolutely worth the price of admission!

Good:

Very fun to play, easy to pick up and hard to master (I can't make it beyond the Hard difficulty). I love this visual style, reminicent of the old Tron movie mixed with some polygon backgrounds from the old Virtual Boy era. Sense is scale is really nice, feels like you are in a big hall/hangar. One thing I absolutely loved was the haptic feedback of the racket. It has this long veil/ribbon streaming out of the back and as you move it, you feel it swoosh around. Really sold me on having that sci-fi racket in my hand instead of the Vive controller.

Bad:

A bit barebones with regards to gameplay modes and options, but the base game has enough to offer initially. Future updates should include more modes (many balls come toward you, specific areas of the court give more points/are blocked, etc) and possibly power-ups (more balls, racket size changes etc). Multiplayer would also be very cool but it would require big changes to the gameplay (can't go as high vertically). One final note of warning: make sure you have a lot of space or stand as far back as you can! I have about 2.8x2.3m and was so immersed and focused on winning and smashing the ball that I scratched the controller on the wall twice in a row the first time I played it. I had no problems being aware of the bounds and not hitting them with any of my other games, so be warned!

reviewText: After the 1.4 update this pretty much plays like an entirely different game. The AI and the physics are much improved, and it\'s a lot more challenging and fun now. Highly recommend if you are looking for a racquetball/tennis sort of game that will give you a decent workout.

reviewText: Having a blast. Reasonable price. Not digging the multiplayer view when controlling the CPU, the controls are hard. Worked up a decent sweat playing this.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText: If Holopoint is the game that will make you hate the Vive's breakout box, Holoball is the game that will make you hate its wrist straps. I personally haven't had any experiences with anyone letting go of the controller yet, but I've seen plenty of evidence elsewhere, and it's a bit telling that Nintendo has suddenly sold out of every color of wrist strap except the basic white, so if you don't always keep a good grip or know someone who might not be too careful then you might want to get a beefier wrist strap before you play this one.\n\nAs for the game itself, it's simple but fun, like most of the cheaper Vive games I've played. It's sort of like pong mixed with tennis, in which you play against an AI. If you've got a spectator they can also take over the AI and play with WASD, but in my experience they won't stand a chance and it's better to just leave it to the computer. There are four difficulties that you unlock as you complete the previous one, and it can be a pretty good workout on the later difficulties. It's not necessarily the sort of thing that's super impressive on a technological level, but for the price it offers a fair amount of entertainment unless you manage to break your wrist strap, in which case the only people being entertained may be the TV repair company.

reviewText: I'm going to keep playing this just for the exercise.

reviewText: For the price Holoball is a steal, but only because the price is so low. The game is beautiful looking and fun to play, but if you're halfway decent you'll have beaten the hardest mode within an hour. The AI needs some serious work. This game will get you to work up a sweat though.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
HOLOlujah! This game is BALLer!

Imagine if the original 1974 Pong, had a baby with a colorful, virtual 3-Dimensional environment. Then, that child grew up, and had a baby with the classic indoor sport of racquetball. That wonderful, miracle, of a baby, is named; HoloBall!

HoloBall is a competitive sport-like game in which takes place in what appears to be a neon version of a racquetball court. The goal is to win against a snarky, sarcastic, comedic AI, and attempting to get the highscore to get your name up on the leaderboard. Doing so, immenses a challenge and a great amount of fun! The different difficulty levels, really help to match your level of skill. The harder the difficulty, the larger the court and the smaller the ball. The racket has perfect physics! It feels all so very natural swinging at the ball attempting to get it passed the AI. Not only is this game a large amount of fun, its a great workout too if you really get into it!

I highly recommend purchasing this game for anyone who even has a slight interest in; Racquetball, Tennis, or even the original Pong.

Warning: DON'T LET GO OF YOUR CONTROLLER! (Racket)

reviewText: Very enjoyable game for the Vive. First game I bought and always a go to game to get a little work out in. The new Custom Mode is fun as well!

reviewText: I love this game and play it as much as I can. The newest update gives a really solid feel to the game and ups the difficulty to a level that is frustrating, but fun. Can't wait to get back and play it again.

reviewText:
Update - The devs have added more music so yay! It sounds good, too.

Great game. Good fun, very satisfying, and you'll never have to go to the gym again. The game is definitely a workout. The only thing I don't like about it right now is that there's only one music track. Maybe the developer will add some more, but it's not bad as it is.

But BE CAREFUL. I had someone try it out and while playing, the wrist strap on the controller SNAPPED OFF and he lost his grip and the controller flew into the wall and stopped working. Thanks to a guide I found online I was able to fix it by opening it up and reconnecting a strip, but it's much better to not have your controllers break at all. So hold those controllers tight when you're playing this game! I would even recommend putting something different on for a wrist strap. I use the ones from the Wii controllers now.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I was lucky enough to get an early access copy of the game on reddit. So while I played a paid copy of the game, I won't let this influence this review.


As someone enjoying sports involving rackets like Tennis or Badminton, I feel like this game is absolutely fantastic fun! Let's start with the concept. You hit a ball with a racket, either with your left or right hand, and watch as it travels towards a huge wall covered by a floating AI opponent platform. Said CPU tries to return the ball and the goal of course is to get the ball past the player. It's basically pong meeting squash. There are three alternate modes: „Zen“ is classic squash, with the player having to repeatedly hit the ball of a wall. Then there are three different difficulties for matches against an AI, each consisting of five games, first to score five wins a game. Players are rewarded points for winning and performing bonus actions like an ace serve, but get points substracted for time spent. In this highscore-based mode it's all about time basically. To round the content of, „Endurance“ has you playing against a bot with only three lives to survive. Fundamentally, you have to score as many points as possible without letting the ball get past you more than two times. While each mode contains more or less the same key gameplay elements, they still all play diverse. Zen is best played rather slow, as you want the ball to travel as slow as possible to be able to return it as precise as possible over and over again. On the three difficulty enemy encounters, I tend to play more and more aggressively. While „Easy“ really is quite easy, „Medium“ already managed to give me a workout. „Hard“ definitely is a challenge and I tend to absolutely smash the ball whenever possible to get past the enemy. Spanning five rounds each, the AI gets better with the rounds played. It moves faster or returns the ball harder, giving you a great progressive increase of difficulty even within the different modes. „Endurance“ also comes with a change-up in mechanics. While the three other enemy modes have a „sweetspot“ zone on the edges of the wall that you'll definitely want to hit, leaving the enemy no chance to reach it, this zone doesn't exist in Endurance. All my play in the three difficulty modes usually focusses on aiming at the sweetspot-zones, making it feel different to Endurance. Here, you need to out-play the enemy, once again involving forceful smashes and quick directional changes. All of the playing modes ultimately have you hitting the ball, but while incorporating the same mechanics, they still manage to feel different due to varied circumstances.

The actual gameplay is absolutely mad fun! The Vive controller just works awesome as a racket. I'm playing in a 3,8m x 1,8m space and the use of room scaling is fantastic. It can be quite exhausting running from one end to the other, though it never seemed unfair in my time with it. When the ball came through, I always knew I was too slow. All in all it feels like a work out, but a very fun one. As hard as I kept hitting the balls, I felt sore muscles just few hours later the first time I played it. The game encourages me to use both arms, as each hand is equipped with a racket. While you theoretically still can play with one controller using forehand and backhand hits, you're way better off using both. I'm usually terrible at doing anything with my non-dominant arm and as the game encourages me to still use it, I think it actually helps me getting better with it. At the start I couldn't hit a ball with it, but it has already gotten better at the end of my first session and it keeps improving. Haptic feedback on the controllers makes the swinging all the more satisfying.

One of the most fun experiences I've had in VR with the Vive so far has been jump-smashing a ball to victory. It feels so satisfying to run and jump, smashing the ball with as much force as possible. It makes me feel really bad-♥♥♥, especially if it's still precisely aimed at a sweetspot zone. The game becomes a frantic, awesome work out on both the Hard difficulty and Endurance, as the enemy tends to return the ball harder and harder. My reflexes are greatly tested as the ball can come back in any direction in my 3,8m playspace width. Smash the ball and you face quite a workout with the enemy giving you a real challenge.


With all the talk about smashing a controller around, I didn't come close to hitting any furniture or walls in my time with the game so far. There's a room requirement for a reason, and I think as long as you have the required 1.5m x 2m or greater, you're good to go. The room scale use seems perfect and thanks to Chaperone, I'm sure there won't be a case of destroyed furniture or controller :p I ended up hitting myself with the controllers though which is a first for me with the Vive. The heavy hitting makes it difficult to slow the controllers down in time in some occasions and thus I hit myself regularly in my first hour. The more I played though, the less this happened. But a short, important advice: It seems crucial to wear the controller wrist straps. All the smashing in combination with slippery hands can make controllers fly through the room. I actually had a controller slip happen to me, while wearing the straps though – thankfully. So remember to use them or you'll regret it.

Visually, the game is looking great. The neon colors are vibrant, though the black largely black background keeps it light on the eyes. The controller rackets feature some cool visual effects, but I would suggest not to hold them directly in front of your eyes – they are very bright. The visuals give me a Tron-esque vibe and it feels great. The sense of space is fantastic! Depending on the game mode and difficulty, you play in a smaller or larger hall. Especially the large one really impresses with the threedimensional portrayal and with the ball traveling longer than in the small room, it's part of the reason why this game feels very immersive. I tend to forget that I'm wearing the Vive and that is always a good sign! The CPU is trash-talking to you during play which is fun, even though its lines become repetitive after some matches.

With the most important aspects out of the way, there are some miscellaneous things I want to talk about. The menus are fantastic, very intuitive. All the modes are right in front of you (though you have to unlock some by completing the previous ones first) and you choose a mode by putting the controller into the respective icon. On top of that, the game has super quick loading times which always is a great plus in my book. I'd appreciate another way to access the leaderboards. Currently, you can see it before starting a new match. As an arcade game pretty much revolving around highscores, I would appreciate a simpler way of having a quick look at the leaderboard. Also, I tend to press the Vive home button when things get heated so I'd wish for an option to disable all button presses while playing. Nitpicking though :) The game feels very polished and I've yet to face any kind of bug.Just a short disclaimer: All of my experience is based on the build that I played on the weekend before official release. I didn’t see any patch provided so I assume the final version is the exact same as I played. As polished as it is, there’s no real need for a patch anyway.


Holoball is a very fun experience and I can see myself playing this every day for some small workout. Three modes with increasing difficulties play more diverse than I thought and chasing highscores quickly got me hooked. The price of 10 bucks is great and if you can imagine yourself having at least a tiny bit of fun equipped with two rackets, smashing every ball the AI is testing you with, I can fully recommend the game to you. If you don't mind a little workout, you're in for an insanely fun game that has you jump-smashing ball for ball like a badass!
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
This is way more fun than I thought it was going to be, seriously.
Depending on how much space you have in your living room setup for VR it might make you chase a ball here or there.
I thought I would be standing in one spot, but with room scale that is not the case.
I either suck or I'm really bad at this game but on my first try the game bested me on easy.
Awesome 80s feel, simple, and a ton of fun.
This is one of those must have's for the HTC VIVE.

reviewText: CAUTION! CAUTION! This game can cause your Vive wrist straps to break. If you swing to hard and lose your grip you can snap the weak straps. Buy some stronger straps or reinforce the current ones.\n\nStill this is one of my favorite VR games right now.
Very physically demanding game. Kinda like virtual squash. I didn't play very long, because I was scared for my controllers and living room inventory.
This game will kill your legs and arms. Great!
Tons of fun, its pong but more active. feels like i've just played squash. Great 80's neon vibe. Don't know how replayable the game is but I really want to get on that leaderboard.
Take indoor squash tennis, a futuristic setting, an evil robot voice, and you get Holoball.\nIt's really fun, nothing more to say.\n
Really fun game.\n\nBrings back memories of an old flash game called Curveball". This is even better and more addictive."
Lightsaber Training 10/10

I usually don't write any review, I'm too lazy. I got this game only because it was really cheap, didn't like the video, didn't like the screenshots but all the reviews were positive, so I just wanted to give it a shot, worst case I'd return it after 10 minutes.\n\nINSTEAD, I think I'm going to throw so many hours in this game. I think after one minute it was already in my top 3! It's so fun and addictive!!! and the graphics is just perfect, it had this Tron feeling all over. The controls are well tuned, and the possibilities for future updates are countless. VERY GOOD WORK, even at full price it would be a must have game! I'm thinking about selfie tennis and its price...and then this one....just do yourself a favour, buy it!
Another great VR game for some quick workout.

As a masters squash player who long ago tried not to run too much on a squash court I can give Holoball my seal of approval.\n\nGameplay is very simple and intuitive, ideal for someone wanting to have a quick go at VR without too much of a learning curve, also not bad to work a bit of a sweat up...but that maybe  just be because I'm a out of shape :-)

voteText: 1 person found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I'm a casual racquet ball/tennis player, and after the update this game is now better than ever.

Before the update, this was a great game.  The core game was solid, but my only gripe was that each shot felt more like a ricochet rather than an actual swing. When I would serve the ball with all my might, sometimes it'd be a cannon, and sometimes it'd be a dud. You'd get a lucky defensive shot ricochet with power into the AI's sweet spot. You really just had to make contact to stay competitive with expert AI.

Since the update, ALL these problems have been resolved.  EVERY Time I serve, it zooms across the court like I intended.  Also, those fast serves get a FAST return volley.  If you serve with power, be prepared to react within a split second. Now my defensive shots are slow and easy for the AI to pick up. Against harder AI, you truly have to earn each point and smash the ball into their sweet spot.

It also now gives you a warning to use your wrist straps and perhaps replace your Vive straps with Wii straps. I am a victim of Vive straps breaking off, causing the controller to fly into the wall.  You do not want a $110 repair bill from HTC support. Trust me.

Great game: A must buy for racquet ball, tennis, squash players, or anyone with a mild interest in racquet sports really.
♥♥♥♥, was ok before, changed the physics, now it's ♥♥♥♥. Stay away

An absolute must have VR game.

I find myself coming back to this every single night.

Highly addicting!

An absolute must have VR game.

You can't afford to pass this game up at the $6 promotional price. This game is in the same vein as Audioshield. If you like Audioshield, then you will enjoy HoloBall for sure!

reviewText: Closest I've felt so far to feeling like I'm on The Grid. Challenging and tons of fun! I got beaten on Easy mode quite a few times and finally won in a super close match!

reviewText: This is hands down the best game for your Vive. I have played many other games and the feeling of accomplishment just isn't matched anywhere else. I play a lot of tennis and this is the closest game to mimic that feeling of playing a tennis match, especially on the later difficulties. The price can't be beat either! Do yourself a favor and pick this up immediately... You'll thank me!!!
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Okay, this was a total suprise game for me.

Very, very simple, harkening to Pong.

But you have two paddles. and have to move in the space against a more and more difficult foe: Who will cheat, mid you, becomming bigger and faster at the game goes on.

I sorta rolled my eyes when playing it on easy, but yeah, Medium starts to work up sweat. Still stuck on the final round on it, but then again it just might be my arm getting sore from swinging so much as you have to make the ball move fast inorder to avoid a time penalty to score.

Downside is that when ever my frames dip slightly so that , it seems like the collission detection goes off. With graphics like these its odd that it is lagging quite a bit on a minspec VR Capable" computer (equilevant to 970).

Hopefully they can work out some optimization in.


Could also use some more old school synth music too.

But otherwise

but this one got me going.

reviewText:
I did not care for this one at all.  The play area increases through advancement but found that it would have the ball coming in too deep to the sides outside the chaperone area.  This basically invites you to swing outside the chaperone area which can be bad news.

Also, the play was pretty dry.  I don't see why people are throwing controllers out of hands as how hard you swing does not play in how the ball behaves.  Not enough options for play just hit the ball against the wall.

At least it is not steeply priced.  But it is not my cup of tea at all.

reviewText:
Looked fun. Wasn't.

The feedback for striking a hit is pretty unnoticeable, if it's there at all, leaving you to wonder if you hit the ball if you weren't looking directly at it. The color choice also hinders this issue since the paddles, paddle trails, and the ball all are the same exact color. This results in very unsatisfying and hard to visually parse gameplay.

The audio mixing is unbearable. The music comes across like static most of the time and overpowers all other audio ques and dialogue. If there's an option to adjust this in the settings I couldn't say because...

...The menus are completely unusable. They appear outside the place space, meaning you can't physically get to them to touch. There seems to be no other means of interacting with them resulting in you stuck but to quit to home after every match.

I got borded after few minutes and as it was seemingly all there was to this game, I refunded it.

reviewText: This is the first game I played where the wrist straps on the controllers became a necessity.\n\nThe fact that I got into it enough to put in the effort that this was an issue is, to me, a sign of high praise. It's enough of a workout (to my slightly overweight, sedentary self) to test the sweat-absorbing capabilities of the face pad, too. And at the same time, fun enough to play a few rounds to work up that sweat, making it a more consistent exercise" option than
recommended: actual exercise.\n\nIt's not like it's complex
voteText: but it doesn't need to be. It gets you moving in a fun way. And since that makes it WAY cheaper than a treadmill

reviewText: Great game, recommend it! Though needs more modes :( Only so many times you can do the same thing over and over really.
Sporty VR tennis" game. Especially on the higher difficulties challenging and exhausting. The Tron 90's arcade style makes it look great. I would say a must have for VR."
Resisted buying this at first, as it looked too simple. Well, it is simple, but it's really satisfying.

This simple game is the reason i have a controller mark on my wall...

It's hilarious and fun.
But please bear in mind that you have some physical world restrictions and remember your walls. Don't end up like me.

No seriously, I like it!
If you like pong or squash, go for it.
A must have for any VR-Owner!

Saw the game on sale so I decied to try it. WOW! This is virutal racket ball. Very well done. room scales to what size room you have. Man got a good workout too. This is wath room scale is all about. Lots of fun!
Wow!  If you want a workout play this game!  Good graphics and good AI.  One of my favorite for the Vive, and I've tried a few.
Tron racketball. Be careful not to throw your controllers. Use those straps. Can hardly wait for multiplayer.

The game is simply too simple for the price. I would expect much more interesting AI behaviour, powerups and much better ball physics like topspins etc. My only problem is the price. I would find this game around 2-3 bucks. I would rather give a neutral recommendation, but steam does not support that.

Pros:
The gameplay is fast paced and exciting
Difficulties are very well paced
Soundtrack is ♥♥♥♥ing awesome
Very cheap for what you're getting in comparison to some other VR games
Cons:
The paddle coming towards you without warning at the start of the game is terrifying
The ball sometimes goes very, very close to the chaparone bounds which can sometimes break the immersion as you become conscious of your surroundings
I would absolutely reccomend this game to anyone with a Vive. It's a lot of fun and I look forward to playing it more.
I had a chance to play this pre-release. The game is a blast to play. Think pong for VR." Three modes: one zen (basically you hit it with yourself)
hoursPlayed: which allows you to keep playing until you lose.\n\nBeating the three difficulties doesn't take long
voteText: but climbing the leaderboards provides for something to come back to. The game lends itself perfectly to multiplayer (not yet in)
helpfulPercent: and I can't wait for that.\n\nVery polished as well. Any issues I had with the game were minor (occasionally easy to lose the ball blended against the background
votesHelpful: sweet spot on the AI's wall that gives you an automatic point if you hit it is a little too generous).\n\nOne of the games I most enjoy
votesTotal: and keep thinking about after I'm done playing. "Just one more game.""

reviewText:
I played the Beta version of this game. It's best described as playing squash/ tennis in a tron like environment. Certainly worth owning if you enjoy playing racket based sport games.

That all said, you do need space.  I have a 2.3m x 2.3m play area and whilst it was more than enough to play the game for the most part, I did  bounce off my wall once and hit my light 2 twice so you need clearance above you as well.

Still fun though!
Seems like I always have the most fun with the simplest games on the Vive. HoloBall is no exception. I just completed my first play throug on hard and I'm sweating pretty hard. Great game!
Pong mixed with Racket ball. Fantastic experience and for the price it's a steal.

I thought I'd check this out since it's cheap. Played for two hours non-stop, screaming and sweating, Don't even try this if you have a low ceiling or low hanging ceiling lamps. You'll smash something. Guaranteed.\n\nIf they manage to solve latency problems for multiplayer, this is gonna be a must-have game. Well, it already is.

My tennis loving buddies are going to love this. It's really fun and addictive. I can see myself jumping into this once in a while to play and move around. I wish there were more game modes and stuff but its a fun gamefor the first 30 min so far, im at hard now and taking a break. For the $6 sale cost it's worth it.
Gave this a shot. Amazingly fun. LOVE the tron-like music :D
Fun game, a lot of potential.
One of the more engaging early motion control experiences. This made me late for work a few times!
Smacked a guy in the face.\n\n10/10
My favorite Vive game so far. 8/10. Would love to see some power ups or some other type of game mode that gives you a little something different.
A must have for the HTC VIVE!

It seems like every time I play a new game I have a new favorite game.  This one was no different.  Looked cheap and didn't have high hopes, but was blown away by how awesome it really is.  Might be the best value of any non-free VR game out there right now.  Can't wait to see how it grows and to play more.
Buy it if you like table tennis or racket ball. An absolute joy and the mechanics are very fine tuned. must buy, especially for the price!
This game is fun.  I wish there were harder versions.  I've already beat the game and I just bought it.  I'm sure they'll add a difficulty level
Great game for the HTC VIVE
Worth every penny. This is one of those simple games you go back to often, either as a VR warm-up" or for a longer session trying to beat that high score."

I am inside Tron, playing squash against a giant computer that keeps making snarky remarks at me.  Highly recommended for every Vive owner, I will absolutely be playing this daily.  Great workout as well!

This is just like playing racket ball except you are wearing a VR headset.  A really cool title and quite a bit of fun.  Hopefully this will add some more challenges into it as even the hard mode is not that hard.\n\nStill I highly recommend it for the price.  Really shows off some movement with VR.
Destroyed my monitor with a Vive controller, 10/10 would play again.

I almost passed on HoloBall, but a reddit comment brought me back. It told tales of a pong-like game, in which you protect your 80's sports car from an evil robot. I was sold, and I'm having a blast with it.\n\nI'm also a sucker for 80's inspired, neon virtual reality. There's something very enjoyable about getting to participate in a Tron-esque world.
Fun little game.
Very fun room scale game. Simple and fun.  Up there with Space Pirate Trainer.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YmawREAKjiY

Very fun and exhausted game.
I got a chance to get it on sale, and I am so happy.

I always though I was going to make sports with the WII, but this never happend.

With HoloBall this is changing.

At he begining I started just hitting the ball and it was easy, and I though, well another game.

After a while I really wanted to beat the machine and be in the HighScore Ranking.

Very good graphic style, that remainds me the fiml TRON"

Very Good Fun

Fun little game. It doesn't have a ton of depth but the basic mechanics are pretty solid. The gameplay is some of the most exciting high-speed movement you'll experience right now in VR (without the risk of motion sickness). The developer also has plans to add more features, which is always a plus.\n\nRefreshing to have an enjoyable game at a reasonable price in the early VR market!

GREAT game.  This and Audioshield are in daily rotation.  Basically, a spin on racquetball. Its not a very deep game, but very arcadey and a blast to play.  My only complaint is limited MP and the robovoice can be a bit hard to understand (but rest assured, it is mocking you).
The new arcade classic!
Pretty fun game! Now if the added multiplayer it would be a must buy!

Man this is so good. Its so funny when you see it in 2d you think ok they are hitting the ball against the wall. Tthen you get into VR amd its a massive corut, with scores hovering tens of metres above you. It feels glorius.\nI would love to see more variants to the game, but it a real workout and great fun. Love it\n

The game is pretty simple on the surface - it's a mix of pong and racquetball/squash. However, it is incredibly fun and extremely replayable. I can see myself playing this daily for months and months as a fan of racquetball. It already has local multiplayer (one person in the Vive vs the other person controlling the AI paddle with WASD). If they manage to get online multiplayer up and running it'll get even better. There are different difficulty levels which is great for families, everyone can try this. Just make sure to use the wrist straps with this game, quite a few people have let the controllers fly out of their hands when they go for a quick swing.
Wow!  If you want a workout play this game!  Good graphics and good AI.  One of my favorite for the Vive, and I've tried a few.
Tron racketball. Be careful not to throw your controllers. Use those straps. Can hardly wait for multiplayer.

The game is simply too simple for the price. I would expect much more interesting AI behaviour, powerups and much better ball physics like topspins etc. My only problem is the price. I would find this game around 2-3 bucks. I would rather give a neutral recommendation, but steam does not support that.
Great game, recommend it! Though needs more modes :( Only so many times you can do the same thing over and over really.
Highly recommend. Felt like I was playing a future version of racketball!
Very entertaining
Fun AF

This is a great game, and I want to see non local multiplayer. VR Pong, with an AI that with some improvement to personality could rival GLaDOS. You absolutely need a clear space or you risk breaking something.
Vive writebands are breaking and it's happening to people while playing this game. HTC won't count it as a manufacturer defect so the blame must fall on this gae right?
Simple as Pong, but so much fun, Be sure to have plenty of room!!!!!
Great game, recommend it! Though needs more modes :( Only so many times you can do the same thing over and over really.

Good fun, very responsive. Maybe I've looked over it, but the ability to mute just the music would be a welcomed addition. The ball can be a little unpredictable coming off the paddle but it generally feels good. Good way to burn some calories and work on the virtual hand-eye coordination.

HoloBall is definetly my favorite game that I own for the Vive. I end up playing it for a while at a time just trying to beat that last score haha. It totally reminds me of the flash game Curveball" that I used to play all the time online
date: or pong in a TRON world. You control A paddle with each hand to hit a ball and try and get it past the paddle controlled by the a.i in a 3d space. All I can say is this game is some cheap addicting fun. Was well worth the 10.99 price."

reviewText:
This is the kind of game you might think of when imagining a basic VR/Hologram game or what you might see people playing in a SciFi tv show or something. It's sort of like raquetball/pong against a computer. and it's FUN. It can be a simple enjoyable game or an intense workout depending on your difficulty setting.

I love the choice in layout, the fireworks and rave-like lighting is pretty cool and the music is pretty hype. I always find myself dancing when I score and get that sweet music.

Super fun game! I recommend it for sure!

The gameplay from the very begining is quite fun, and the lower difficulties make it easy to jump in and get the hang of the game, but the higer difficulties keep the game as challenging as you want it to be. The visual design is very nice as well. Overall, this is a great game that I can highly reccomend getting.

AWESOME. I put off getting this... (another BREAKOUT?) then was on sale and boughtit and never tried it.

Pros

FUN
neat computer voice
excersize!
Great VR (vive paddles)
VIEWS  multiple camera views!  hope more games do this.
2 PLAYER!!!  one in VR the other on monitor. (HOWEVER only found KB control (worthless) needs game pad

2 player controller appears to be WSDA or some such HORRIBLE control (needs Xbox controller or mouse!)

I recommend it highly - PLEASE fix the two  "cons". !!!"
One of my favortire VR games out there right now. Maybe its that tron-esque game art, or the synthwave music, but I keep coming back it to it. Expert mode is a pretty dang good workout.

Love this game, you do work up a sweet. The energy you throw into each session brings you into the game. Message to the devs. Would love to see a double ball mode and to play your own music. Check out the way the game distance works with music, if that could be implemented would be awesome.  But regardless this game is great

The game is pretty simple on the surface - it's a mix of pong and racquetball/squash. However, it is incredibly fun and extremely replayable. I can see myself playing this daily for months and months as a fan of racquetball. It already has local multiplayer (one person in the Vive vs the other person controlling the AI paddle with WASD). If they manage to get online multiplayer up and running it'll get even better. There are different difficulty levels which is great for families, everyone can try this. Just make sure to use the wrist straps with this game, quite a few people have let the controllers fly out of their hands when they go for a quick swing.
The visuals and music are great! I felt like I was in TRON. You will NEED ceiling space, however. I hit my ceiling fan quite a few times, and had to remove it.
Great workout! Love every minute of it.

I put off buying this game for a while because it's basically advertised as Pong in VR, and I've played far too much Pong in my day. I could have never imagined how much fun this game would be though.\n\nEverything about it is very polished, and the end result is that it's like having a racquetball court in your living room, The colorful, holographic art style is perfect for a VR game, the difficulty at the higher levels is definitely enough to give you a challenge (and a workout), and the AI says some pretty funny things. As with almost all VR games out now, it could be longer or have a little more variety in the environments or game modes, but for what it costs, it's worth every penny.
Holy ♥♥♥♥ the future is here and its like pong tennis. Would buy 60 dollar version if Dev wanted to expand into that in the future wink  wink nudge nudge

TBF I had thought this was ♥♥♥♥ when I first gave it a go. Then it popped up on my you need to play this" whatchamacallit and so I did.

It was better than I had previously thought. Like playing pong in VR so being inside pong. In 1979 when my dad brought home a early game system that played pong. It was the ants pants and as this reminded me of that time so I now recommend it to anyone who always wanted to be the bat in pong.

"

Good game, simple and fun.
The controls are precise, reactive and the feeling when hitting the ball is great.
Basic graphics but keep the action easy to read and provide a good sense of scale (arena i.e.)
AI is descent and will surely improve over time
Actually, only one thing is missing to his game, Multiplayer!
This game is great! I keep returning for more play.

It hasn't got a lot content wise right now and only one sound track but it was pretty fun and with enough room you can actually start getting a workout going if you play for a little while. Definitely worth it as long as price range stays $0-10.\n\n*WARNING* You WILL throw your controller on accident, upgrade the strap on the Vive controller as it is garbage, someone mentioned Wii Mote strap, I second that.
Fantastic game. So much fun. Devs are going to update it soon. I'm looking fw to it.
Simple a fun, nothing special but for the price worth it. Nice to just play a few min now and then.

Pros:

-Most [physically] active VR game
-Amazing music that feels dystopian
-Not a lot of turning so your cable won't twist and you can play longer
-Minor footwork that can be done slow so you don't step on your cables

Cons

-Major damage risk to your furniture
-Major damage risk to the vive controllers
-Ball goes right to the edge of your play space (not a problem if you are focused on the paddle hitting the ball, NOT the controller)
-If your hands sweat you will probably let go of the controller and break your straps

Overall

Super fun and simple. Worth the asking price for the health value!

great simple fun, just careful where you hurl your controller at, this game could get some little child or pet killed, I'm not making a stupid joke, this game is dangerous but it is a lot of fun and one serious workout
Bought tonight, wasn't expecting much to be honest. But, it's actually a lot of fun,\nTime flew by and I feel like I've had a workout. This VR lark might actually get me fit.

After the update I noticed a few issues:

Zen Mode: Zen Mode is now a little buggy. The longer you play the more the game lags. I noticed the ball would random \jump" to a different place. After prolonged playing the entire game will start to jitter. I think is has to do with the leader board seeming to load in real time.

Custom Mode: I noticed if you turn the AI's stats all the way up
date: the ball just explodes on contact.."

reviewText: Great fun, relaxing or hectic if you want it. Still being updated, and makes for not only a great introductory Vive experience to break you into the movement and barriers, but also a wonderful arcade experience in its own right. 3D tron-Pong works very well for the Vive, and if you have a Vive, this is a good buy.

This is, simply put, a masterstroke.  Simplicity, well-executed. HoloBall takes concepts like Pong, Racketball, and Tennis, and put a whole other spin on it.  At times, I fondly recall the original Atari, and, others, Portal (GladOS comparisons, and such).

The game is polished and fun. If you have a VIve, get this.  Just get it.

EDIT: The new updates make the game more compelling, and the developers are workinf around-the-clock to polish the update.  Great game, great dev!

Pros:
+ One of the best VR games on Steam
+ One of the best value for the money
+ High replayability
+ One of the best VR games for a good workout
+ High fun factor

Cons:
- Only one stage

This game is very satisfying to play, and is a game that fits vr very well. Great to play alone or with friends. Devs seem to be rolling out updates and want to improve the game. Would recommend at the $10 price point

I don't know maybe you need a large room to run around in for this to be fun, because I'm just standing here smackin a ball back and forth, not getting much excercise but my shoulder is killing me, this game is way overhyped. i've only played after the 1.4 update, maybe it was better before?
Bought tonight, wasn't expecting much to be honest. But, it's actually a lot of fun,\nTime flew by and I feel like I've had a workout. This VR lark might actually get me fit.
I had a great time with this. A great raquet ball like experience.

I\'m currently sitting half naked to cool down nursing a dead arm from playing round after round of holoball. This is great fun, if you\'ve ever played any kind of racket game the skill actually transfers quite well and feels realistically satisfying to smack the crap out of the ball and challenge the high scores.

reviewText:
I've been ignoring this because similar style games like SPT don't do much for me, but I decided to give it a shot because of the reviews. It's INCREDIBLE. I felt like I was in some sort of dystopian future, battle to the death with an AI. The mechanics are fantastic. The 2D screenshots don't do the graphics justice, because being inside a Tron style world just completes the game.

When a good volley starts going you can't help but really attack the ball, which gets to the point of visceral catharsis. My 2.5m x 3m playspace with a low ceiling doesn't let me get too nuts, but I'd imagine a larger playspace with a ceiling you can't reach would be insane.

I've played at least 10 other titles on my Vive, and while this might not be the most complicated, it's the most fun I've had.

What a game!  If you have a Vive you owe it to yourself to own this.  Having gamed for over 30 years i can honestly say that when i play this it feels like i have entered the future!  A simple concept and very Tron-esque but with a pumping soundtrack and increasing difficulty as you progress through the skill levels.  After ten minutes in this game you should feel like you have had a workout.  This game for me does what Kinect Sports didn't do for Xbox.  Superbly implemented, great physics and accuracy and an immense sense of immersion.

If you don't own a VIve then this should be a great reason to get one..!

Now to figure out how i fit my sweat band on...

Holoball is a very simple and satisfying VR experience. Anyone who has ever played tennis or raquetball will be able to pick this up without any explanation. The environment is colorful, immersive, and extremely 80's. Playing gives me a sense of nostalgia, because it is everything people thought VR would be like three decades ago.

You will work up a sweat in the higher difficulties, and may need to 'air-out' your HMD every few minutes.

At $10, this is a great price-point for Holoball. The music is great, and the gameplay is surprisingly responsive for the speed of the game. It is a great game to demo for those new to VR. The only improvement I can think to make is updating the voice of the robot overlord narrator. Although the banter is funny, it is just a little hard to hear.
VR pong. Good stuff that doesn't get old. I could do without the music, though.
